reviewText: While this Viking/swords and sorcery "epic" is anything but a comedy, I have to admit I laughed wholeheartedly throughout.Lee Majors leads a rag-tag group of Norsemen to America to find lost comrades, only to be rudely greeted by a band of especially sadistic Indians whose hobby seems to be poking out tourists' eyes with burning sticks of firewood. The slow-motion battle sequences, complete with thundering musical score, reminds one of an XFL football game, though I must admit "The Norseman" predates that colorful sport by several decades.I rather enjoyed the list of established character actors, including Cornel Wilde and Jack Elam, furrow their overgrown eyebrows while praying to Odin after the death of yet another Viking caught in the wrong place at the wrong time. Several former football players, among them Deacon Jones (yes, Deacon Jones) provide picturesque blocks to weak Native American offensive lines, and there's even Susie Coelho playing a female squaw with the proper fashion sense to wear her buckskin as short as a Nancy Sinatra mini-skirt. That's the pioneer spirit!I actually enjoyed this wild adventure, if for no other reason than it reminds me of my own youth, sitting in a darkened theater during a Saturday afternoon matinee, guzzling Mr. Pibb and voraciously swallowing Lemon Drops while listening to Lee Majors deliver lines like...."What say you Wizard! When will the Gods show us land!"Roger Corman, no doubt, is proud.

reviewText: No great special effects. However, the acting is superb, costumes look great, script and plot are exciting. It is not a BLOODY movie. Just some good old fashion NORSE violence. If it comes out on DVD i will immediately purchase it.

reviewText: You seem to think the idea of a black viking as laughable, but the vikings were one of the few cultures to allow captured slaves to earn higher status through personal achievement. If said black man embrassed the joy of battle His bonds of servitude would have indeed been severed,& part of this would have included giveing him a sword as all free viking males had a right to bare arms. as far as Lee Majors outfitt looking roman that is ridiculous his helm & mask were very indicative to anglo-saxon apparel right down to the eagle crested helmet.As far as the mask goes remember these men spent most of thier lives in the blinding glare of snow & sun reflection off the ocean, think about it, its like a pro football player blackening underneath his eyes to cut down glare. as far as the indian maiden falling in love with the blinded viking warrior that is also not a stretch as many native american cultures placed a high value on stregnth & were not as inclinded towards color based pregidous but valued a person for there deeds & actions. I think for the budget this movie was given it was highly entertaining & well written,that is if you know anything about history. I think the blinded vikings escape was cleaverly done. being filmed in florida made the flora a little odd but hey this was a Majors-Fawcett production so we do have budget issues, nice to see Cornell Wilde & Jack Elam involved truely this film must have been more a labor of love than a attempt to create a box office smash. I just wish they would release a dvd version of this movie. This is probabley a closer portrail of the Lief Ericson expeditions than pathfinder or valehalla rising or severed ways. according to more recent discoveries it appears that the vikings may have been in america alot longer than previously believed.e,i the finding of ruin stones in minnasota. Undoubtabley the native americans must have quickly realized the vikings had very little to offer them culture wise as there main objective was to kill & steal not to teach metal urgy & farming tecniques. So the natives probabley started out helping these strange ironmen from the sea until they realized there threat then banded together in a tecumsa like effort to rid them selves of these ultra violent marines. so grab a history book and rethink this movie. P.s. I do agree Iron Maiden does rock!
summary: retort to rambleing iron maiden fan!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sorry, but it called for an Iron Maiden reference.  And while Maiden's song paints a very violent and epic image of invading Viking hordes, this film almost comes across as a parody of those images.  Now, I certainly don't mind a film that looks like it's made for ten bucks-Hell, I enjoy that-but make it interesting for Odin's sake!  At less than 90 minutes this movie is a cure for insomnia, and it's not for a lack of action sequences, just a lack of remotely interesting action sequences.Lets back up here-The Norseman is the story of balls of steel Viking warrior, Thorvald, played by....Lee Majors? More on that later.  So, The Six Million Dollar Viking leads a group of mighty Norsemeeeeeeeeeennnn(sorry for the Iron Maiden thing again) on a longship cruise to America(which the Norsemen call "Vineland") to search for Thorvald's father, who had made a similar expedition years before and never returned.  Upon reaching the shores of "Vineland", Thorvald and his crew are attacked by a tribe of hostile Native Americans.  This is pretty much the whole film.  It's a series of battles between Native Americans and Vikings.  Seems that Thorvald's father, Eurich is indeed alive and has been a prisoner(not a free man, and his blood's not his ooowwwwwn nowwwwww-Damn It!  Sorry again!) along with his crew.  All of them had their eyes burned out because one of the Vikings was putting the eye on one of the Native American gals.  Battles ensue and the mighty Norsemen sail off into the sunset after a mighty victory.This film was written and directed by Charles B. Pierce, one of the Corman stable, who has made some pretty cool movies in his time....just not this one.One of the main problems here is Lee Majors.  I've got nothing against Lee Majors.  Like any decent red blooded American citizen, I love The Six Million Dollar Man and the Fall Guy(and of course the cameo in Scrooged), but Majors plays just about the most unconvincing Viking ever put on film.  Why?  Because he's Lee Majors and makes no attempt to look and act like anyone but Lee Majors.  His lack of accent, his look, it's Lee Majors.  Then there's his outfit-he dresses like a Roman centurion with a Zorro mask!  In fact, he looks like he's been transplanted from a different movie.  The rest of the Vikings look like Vikings, just on a budget.  One of them is black.  This is starting to sound like a Mel Brooks film here.  Look, I'm sure there were black Vikings at some point in history, but considering how silly this movie is to begin with, that only fuels the fire.  Naturally, the Native Americans are not played by Native American actors, but by Latinos and tan white folks.  Though if I were Native American I'd probably pass on starring in this movie as well(and start running for the hills....ugh) considering how they are portrayed.  No characterization is given to them whatsoever.  They are just a brutal, savage mob standing in the Vikings' way.  Now I know that both the Native Americans and the Vikings in real life were not saints, and there's no need to really portray them as saints.  Both groups were vicious, badass warriors, and probably did some pretty horrible things, but showing Vikings as heroic good guys and Native Americans as soulless brutes is just plain silly.And why in these movies does there always have to be a sympathetic Native American that turns on their tribe to help out the opposition?Well, anyway, I think I've rambled on enough about this.  Suffice to say that everything about this movie is very uninteresting.  The one star in my rating gos to the black Viking, and the Viking named Olaf.Children Of The Daaaaaaaaaamned!  That had nothing to do with anything, but I figured I'd throw in one more Maiden reference for good measure.
summary: Many Nordic fighting men their swords and shields all gleam in the sun
Title: N/A

reviewText: Drumroll please for The Norseman... Being the heroic tale of a band of Vikings who venture across the waters in their long ship Raven-in-the-Wind to Vineland (Florida to you and me), where the treacherous Indian chief Kiwonga (Jacob Jerry Daniels) is holding Mel Ferrer, the blinded father of our eponymous hero, to grind corn. And boy, do they get through corn at a rate of knots in this joyously misbegotten venture.It's the kind of movie where you keep on expecting Tony Curtis to turn up and say "Yonda lies da teepee od my fadda," but instead have to make do with Lee Majors failing spectacularly to capitalise on the success of The Six Million Dollar Man. Even more so than Tom Selleck in Christopher Columbus, you just have to feel sorry for the poor man. Wearing a Zorro mask under his helmet in a vain attempt to hide his embarrassment, he doesn't even make it to the level of Jon Hall in his Maria Montez days."To go into the forest after them is worse than crossing the high Alps to kill the white bear with empty hands," warns Jack Elam's wizard the Death Dreamer, who keeps on turning his face away at the camera at every available opportunity. (This is a minor plot point, but he's probably just using that as an excuse.) Curiously for this kind of film, the Indians don't speak American, which is odd, since the Vikings do, none more so than Lee Majors' Thorvald. Somewhat hampered in his portrayl of a heroic Viking by his inability to say words like "Oden" (rhymes with loadin') and "Noars-mun" (rhymes with oarsman), imagine a disinterested, slightly embarrassed Nick Nolte with a cold and a bad mood and you have some idea of his vocal interpretation.The Vikings may look like a cross between Hells Angels and ZZ Top roadies but there are at least some good production values for such obviously cut-price fare - the odd oil tanker may stray into shot, but at least the microphone never does - but despite cinematographer Robert Bethard's more than competent efforts, aside from a mini-Viking funeral near the beginning it looks like nothing so much as a Seventies TV movie that somehow was accidentally shot in Scope, all sharp focus and limited shadow.They don't save the first Viking to get killed on the beach because the Indians attack at 24 frames per second while the Vikings, clearly inspired by Majors' Six Million Dollar exploits, can only run in slow motion, like a Dark Ages Baywatch. Their battles with those pesky Injuns are riddled with slo-mo as well. Although much of it looks a hell of a lot better than the normal speed action it is clumsily intercut with, you do end up thinking that if the film was run at normal speed it would only be half an hour long.As the young Eric, the hero's brother, the director's sprog Chuck Pierce Jr doesn't speak for half an hour. When he does, it becomes obvious that his mom was an Okie, although he obviously lost his accent in later years if the narration is anything to go by. Other great casting includes an Injun slave driver played by Kathleen Freeman, here strikingly made up to look like Anthony Zerbe, and Christopher Connelly as a black Viking called Rolf straight out of Studio 54. Although they have a black Viking along, they obviously forgot to bring the comic relief along. Thankfully, with a script like this they don't need one.Denny Miller, the star of MGM's disastrous 1959 remake of Tarzan the Ape Man, a stock footage fest with a Shorty Rogers (!!!) score that sank without a trace at the box-office, is also along for the ride, but of the rest of the cast, only Cornel Wilde looks comfortable in this sort of thing, but then, he did have a lot of practice at this sort of thing in the good old days.It's not so much laugh out loud, more a cumulative "They must have known" factor. Well, at least the weather stayed nice for them.
summary: "To go into the forest after them is worse than crossing the high Alps to kill the white bear with empty hands."

reviewText: Yikes! I only saw the last 20 minutes or so on TV as the "indians" were chasing the vikings back to their boat but it was really bad. I am sure the gang from Mystery Science Theater could have turned this into a masterpiece. Even without their commentary, I found it impossible to turn away from this train wreck! I no longer own a VHS player and hope it comes on TV again. I went with one star but may revise if I ever see the entire "film".
